awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A meta-omics approach to discover the determinants of micropollutant biotransformations performed by wastewater microbial communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to improve water quality through enhanced wastewater treatment to protect public health and improve the environment. Many types of pollutants are poorly removed by existing wastewater treatment technologies. As a result, pollutants accumulate in aquatic environments and may contaminate drinking water resources. The PI will study the mechanisms by which organic pollutants are transformed during wastewater treatment through detailed characterization of the complex organic matter in wastewater using advanced chemical analysis tools. This information will be coupled with next generation genetic characterization of the microbes responsible for pollutant removal to allow optimization of wastewater treatment plant performance to more efficiently remove pollutants and decrease cost. The education plan for this project will train a diverse group of students to broaden participation in environmental engineering and other STEM fields.

The occurrence of anthropogenic organic micropollutants in wastewater treatment plant effluents raises concerns about their human-health and ecological impacts. As wastewater reclamation and recycling become more widely adopted, efficient and cost-effective means for micropollutant removal are becoming essential. This research seeks to leverage the broad metabolic capabilities of wastewater microbial communities to achieve this goal. The research will utilize high-resolution mass spectrometry to broadly infer the metabolic functioning of microbial communities and next-generation sequencing to characterize the structure of microbial communities from population to functional levels with a goal of identifying taxa, ecological features, metabolic pathways, or operational parameters that lead to enhanced micropollutant biotransformation. This research is significant because it will provide wastewater utilities with an effective means for optimizing bioprocesses to meet emerging performance objectives. The PI will create opportunities for diverse groups of students across all education levels to engage with water quality research through a collaboration with the Cayuga Lake Floating Classroom for pre-college students, recruit undergraduate students to work on the research plan through the NSF-funded Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program, and integrate research and education activities in the undergraduate environmental engineering curriculum at Cornell University. The education plan is significant because it will create opportunities for students to explore water quality problems outside the classroom and develop skills in self-directed learning in environmental engineering or other STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: CAREER: A meta-omics approach to discover the determinants of micropollutant biotransformations performed by wastewater microbial communities

PI: Damian E. Helbling, Cornell University

Federal Award ID: 1748982 

Introduction: This project outcomes report highlights the key findings of the National Science Foundation (NSF) project titled, “CAREER: A meta-omics approach to discover the determinants of micropollutant biotransformations performed by wastewater microbial communities.” This research project aimed to discover the ways that microbial communities in wastewater treatment plants biotransform or biodegrade trace organic chemicals found in wastewater such as pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products. This research was important for discovering new ways to optimize wastewater treatment processes to better remove chemicals of concern and for informing advances in green chemistry aimed at designed more biodegradable molecules. These outcomes will improve water quality and protect environmental and public health. The project also supported undergraduate research and recruitment of scholars from underrepresented groups.

Optimizing wastewater treatment processes: One major focus of this project was on improving our fundamental understanding of the temporal variability in the functioning of wastewater microbial communities. Previous observations have demonstrated that some chemicals of concern can be removed from wastewater to varying degrees over time. However, neither the time-scales over which this variability occurs nor have the types of biotransformations that exhibit this type of temporal variability have been explored. We conducted a two-week sampling campaign at the influent and effluent of a local wastewater treatment plant and characterized the occurrence of dozens of chemicals of concern in each sample. Through our subsequent analyses, we were able to demonstrate that some microbial community functions exhibit temporal variability on daily time-scales. The types of biotransformations that exhibited the greatest extent of temporal variability included alcohol oxidations, monohydroxylations at secondary or tertiary aliphatic carbons, dihydroxylations of unsubstituted rings, and monohydroxylations at unsubstituted rings. In contrast, we further demonstrated that dehydrogenations, hydroxylations in general, and acetylations are biotransformations that exhibit broad stability. These observations demonstrate that many chemicals of concern have the potential to be biotransformed during wastewater treatment, and that certain processes could be optimized to minimize temporal variability in performance.

Advances in green chemistry: Another major focus of this project was in identifying structural features of chemicals that were more susceptible to biotransformation during wastewater treatment. This is important to inform the design and synthesis of more readily biodegradable chemicals for use in commercial products. We first studied a group of antibiotics to determine whether there were structural features that made them more or less biodegradable. This is important to minimize the occurrence of antibiotics in the environmental and to minimize the proliferation of antibiotic resistance. We found that many antibiotics can be biotransformed during wastewater treatment and that many of the biotransformation mechanisms result in the destruction of the functional group associated with antibiotic activity. We also explored the potential for designing peptide-based antibiotics that have the inherent potential to be biotransformed during wastewater treatment. We identified a set of amino acid pairs that were linked to enzyme-catalyzed hydrolysis and are therefore candidates for incorporation into new and sustainable peptide-based antibiotics. Finally, we performed a broader screening of chemicals of concern to identify specific structural features that were more or less susceptible to biotransformation during wastewater treatment. We identified 30 structural features that we define as either biotransformation promoters, biotransformation inhibitors, structural features that can be biotransformed based on uncharacterized features of the wastewater microbial community, or structural features that are not rate-determining. Together, all of these data can be used to inform the design of new chemical products that may be more readily biodegradable during wastewater treatment.  

Summary: This project made significant advances in our understanding of the potential for wastewater microbial communities to biotransform chemicals of concern. This is important for protecting water quality and for improving environmental and public health.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2024
Modified by: Damian Helbling

Project Outcomes Report 


Award Title: CAREER: A meta-omics approach to discover the determinants of micropollutant biotransformations performed by wastewater microbial communities


PI: Damian E. Helbling, Cornell University


Federal Award ID: 1748982


Introduction: This project outcomes report highlights the key findings of the National Science Foundation (NSF) project titled, CAREER: A meta-omics approach to discover the determinants of micropollutant biotransformations performed by wastewater microbial communities.
